This is the body of the treatise.

Among them, first showing the fruition of the mind of enlightenment, next clarifying the function arising from those causes, the causes having arisen, then the self-nature establishing the appearance of different names, following the place of receiving the body, not being defiled, therefore said to be permanent and harmonious, without the characteristics of other good dharmas corresponding and abiding in the midst of afflictions, called without meaning, emerging from the entanglements and pure, called having meaning, also called one nature, because both are nirvÄá¹‡a.
The twelve kinds of meanings should be understood in sequence.
Among them, what is the fruition of the mind of enlightenment?
Namely, the quiescent extinction nirvÄá¹‡a of the buddhas.
It is also not anything else.
Why is it so?
Because the subtle habitual tendencies have all been severed.
As for no birth, it means the originally unborn nature of the aggregates formed by the mind.
As for no aging, it means the supreme and ultimate increase in the power of quiescent extinction.
As for no illness, it means the complete severance of both the habitual tendencies of afflictions and the obstructions to knowledge.
As for no death, it is because the inconceivable transformation is without end.
As for no aggregates, it is because the ground of beginningless ignorance is completely severed.
As for no faults, it is because all bodily, verbal, and mental actions are without error, and also because one is able to transcend all functions.
By what means do they attain this?
It is because they are able to realize the fruit of nirvana from the cause of not losing the supreme skillful means that arises from the mind of enlightenment.
What is called the realm of nirvana?
It is said to be the nature of the inconceivable Dharma realm of all buddhas, the dharma body that is the basis of transformation, which is the realm of nirvana.
Therefore, I now bow my head to that inconceivable mind of enlightenment, whose cause and effect gradually increase and become brighter, like the waxing moon.
Furthermore, the seed of the mind of enlightenment is the basis upon which all worldly good dharmas and grains depend, like the great earth.
It is the source from which all holy ones' dharma treasures emerge, like the great ocean.
It is the source of the enlightenment trees of all buddhas, the sequential cause, like a seed.
This is the fruit of the bodhi mind.
Furthermore, how can one know that it is in accord with that cause?
Like the prince of a wheel-turning king.

The word great compassion means giving rise to great compassion for all sentient beings, not becoming weary in the cycle of birth and death, and being able to perfect all kinds of wisdom, nourishing the bodhi mind as the wet-nurse.
Furthermore, that cause and condition of the bodhi mind should be known as twofold.
What are the two?
First, the characteristic of being defiled by afflictions; second, the characteristic of the nature of wholesome dharmas.

Among them, the defiled refers to the originally pure and always undefiled mind, which is obscured and defiled by the adventitious dust of afflictions, just like fire, whose original nature is pure, is obscured by ashes, mud, clouds, dust, etc.
It is like fire, jewels, space, and water, whose original natures are undefiled. If separated from ashes, etc., the original natures of fire, etc., are all pure.
All sentient beings are also like this. The originally pure mind of all of them is the same in purity, defiled by greed, etc., afflictions. If separated from greed, etc., the mind attains purity.
How can it be known that the characteristics of pure dharmas are also pure?
The originally pure mind is the basis of all pure dharmas, and all pure dharmas arise from it, because jewels are produced from Mount Sumeru.
The mind of enlightenment is also like this. All skills are perfected, and the four kinds of great perfections are attained. Therefore, it is called the Dharma body of the TathÄgata.
As it is said in the sutra: World-Honored One!
The Dharma body of the Tathagata is the perfection of permanence, the perfection of bliss, the perfection of self, and the perfection of purity.
That Dharma body of the Tathagata is defiled by afflictions and secondary afflictions.
The intrinsically pure mind is explained as a synonym, as it is said in the sutra: Shariputra!

This true suchness of the good Dharma, the essence of the Dharma realm, is associated with the nature of the intrinsically pure mind. I rely on this intrinsically pure mind to speak for the sake of sentient beings, saying it is inconceivable.
Furthermore, that mind, for sentient beings, has ten kinds of functions.
Without distinctions in characteristics, because it is unconditioned.
Without beginning, because it is unborn.
Without end, because it is unceasing.
Unimpeded, because of its intrinsically luminous nature.
With the wisdom of emptiness, one knows that all dharmas have the characteristic of a single flavor, because they are devoid of intrinsic nature.
Devoid of intrinsic nature is devoid of characteristics, because it is apart from the objects of the senses.
Because it is the practice of the sages and the realm of the Buddhas.
Because it is the basis of all dharmas, the basis of defiled and pure dharmas.
It is far removed from permanence, because defiled dharmas are impermanent.
It is far removed from annihilation, because pure dharmas are not annihilated.
This has further distinctions and can be summarized into three aspects.
What is called impure refers to the first, which is called the realm of sentient beings.
